#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=THE SOUL OF NICHOLAS SNYDERS , OR THE MISER OF ZANDAM
#Text=Once upon a time in Zandam , which is by the Zuider Zee , there lived a wicked man named Nicholas Snyders .
#Text=He was mean and hard and cruel , and loved but one thing in the world , and that was gold .
#Text=And even that not for its own sake .
#Text=He loved the power gold gave him -- the power to tyrannize and to oppress , the power to cause suffering at his will .
#Text=They said he had no soul , but there they were wrong .
#Text=All men own -- or , to speak more correctly , are owned by -- a soul ; and the soul of Nicholas Snyders was an evil soul .
#Text=He lived in the old windmill which still is standing on the quay , with only little Christina to wait upon him and keep house for him .
#Text=Christina was an orphan whose parents had died in debt .
#Text=Nicholas , to Christina ’s everlasting gratitude , had cleared their memory -- it cost but a few hundred florins -- in consideration that Christina should work for him without wages .
#Text=Christina formed his entire household , and only one willing visitor ever darkened his door , the widow Toelast .
#Text=Dame Toelast was rich and almost as great a miser as Nicholas himself .
#Text=“ Why should not we two marry ? ” Nicholas had once croaked to the widow Toelast .
#Text=“ Together we should be masters of all Zandam . ”
#Text=Dame Toelast had answered with a cackling laugh ; but Nicholas was never in haste .

#Text=One afternoon Nicholas Snyders sat alone at his desk in the centre of the great semi-circular room that took up half the ground floor of the windmill , and that served him for an office , and there came a knocking at the outer door .
#Text=“ Come in ! ” cried Nicholas Snyders .
#Text=He spoke in a tone quite kind for Nicholas Snyders .
#Text=He felt so sure it was Jan knocking at the door -- Jan Van der Voort , the young sailor , now master of his own ship , come to demand of him the hand of little Christina .

#Text=In anticipation , Nicholas Snyders tasted the joy of dashing Jan ’s hopes to the ground ; of hearing him plead , then rave ; of watching the growing pallor that would overspread Jan ’s handsome face as Nicholas would , point by point , explain to him the consequences of defiance -- how , firstly , Jan ’s old mother should be turned out of her home , his old father put into prison for debt ; how , secondly , Jan himself should be pursued without remorse , his ship be bought over his head before he could complete the purchase .
#Text=The interview would afford to Nicholas Snyders sport after his own soul .
#Text=Since Jan ’s return the day before , he had been looking forward to it .
#Text=Therefore , feeling sure it was Jan , he cried “ Come in ! ” quite cheerily .
#Text=But it was not Jan. It was somebody Nicholas Snyders had never set eyes on before .
#Text=And neither , after that one visit , did Nicholas Snyders ever set eyes upon him again .
#Text=The light was fading , and Nicholas Snyders was not the man to light candles before they were needed , so that he was never able to describe with any precision the stranger ’s appearance .
#Text=Nicholas thought he seemed an old man , but alert in all his movements ; while his eyes -- the one thing about him Nicholas saw with any clearness -- were curiously bright and piercing .
#Text=“ Who are you ? ” asked Nicholas Snyders , taking no pains to disguise his disappointment .
#Text=“ I am a pedlar , ” answered the stranger .
#Text=His voice was clear and not unmusical , with just the suspicion of roguishness behind .
#Text=“ Not wanting anything , ” answered Nicholas Snyders drily .
#Text=“ Shut the door and be careful of the step . ”
#Text=But instead the stranger took a chair and drew it nearer , and , himself in shadow , looked straight into Nicholas Snyders ’ face and laughed .
#Text=“ Are you quite sure , Nicholas Snyders ?
#Text=Are you quite sure there is nothing you require ? ”
#Text=“ Nothing , ” growled Nicholas Snyders -- “except the sight of your back . ”
#Text=The stranger bent forward , and with his long , lean hand touched Nicholas Snyders playfully upon the knee .
#Text=“ Would n’t you like a soul , Nicholas Snyders ? ” he asked .
#Text=“ Think of it , ” continued the strange pedlar , before Nicholas could recover power of speech .
#Text=“ For forty years you have drunk the joy of being mean and cruel .
#Text=Are you not tired of the taste , Nicholas Snyders ?
#Text=Would n’t you like a change ?
#Text=Think of it , Nicholas Snyders -- the joy of being loved , of hearing yourself blessed , instead of cursed !
#Text=Would n’t it be good fun , Nicholas Snyders -- just by way of a change ?
#Text=If you do n’t like it , you can return and be yourself again . ”

#Text=What Nicholas Snyders , recalling all things afterwards , could never understand was why he sat there , listening in patience to the stranger ’s talk ; for , at the time , it seemed to him the jesting of a wandering fool .
#Text=But something about the stranger had impressed him .
#Text=“ I have it with me , ” continued the odd pedlar ;
#Text=“ and as for price -- ”
#Text=The stranger made a gesture indicating dismissal of all sordid details .
#Text=“ I look for my reward in watching the result of the experiment .
#Text=I am something of a philosopher .
#Text=I take an interest in these matters .
#Text=See . ”
#Text=The stranger dived between his legs and produced from his pack a silver flask of cunning workmanship and laid it on the table .
#Text=“ Its flavour is not unpleasant , ” explained the stranger .

#Text=“ A little bitter ; but one does not drink it by the goblet : a wineglassful , such as one would of old Tokay , while the mind of both is fixed on the same thought : ‘ May my soul pass into him , may his pass into me ! ’
#Text=The operation is quite simple : the secret lies within the drug . ”
#Text=The stranger patted the quaint flask as though it had been some little dog .
